questions.text: A young non-smoker with chronic cough and wheezing was diagnosed with α1 antitrypsin deficiency. The following image shows the normal electrophoresis of serum proteins. Which of the following bands (A, B, C, D) becomes thin in this patient?
questions.solution:
In α1 antitrypsin deficiency, the band that is marked as B, representing α1 globulin, becomes thin.

Serum protein electrophoresis is a method of separation and identification of proteins based on their net charge, size, and shape. The largest peak that lies closest to the positive electrode (left corner) is that of albumin since it is present in the largest proportion in plasma. Globulins make up a much smaller fraction of the total serum protein and are represented by smaller peaks to the right. Five globulin categories are represented: alpha-1, alpha-2, beta-1, beta-2, and gamma, with the gamma fraction being closest to the negative electrode (right corner).

A 5-year old child presents to the OPD with excessive dryness in the eyes and difficulty in seeing at night. On examination, cutaneous lesions are seen over the elbows, as shown in the image below. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this cutaneous lesion?
  1. Vitamin A
  2. Vitamin B complex
  3. Vitamin C
  4. Vitamin D
  5. Vitamin E
  6. Vitamin K
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vitamin A deficiency. The cutaneous lesion in the image is phrynoderma, and it can caused by deficiency of vitamins A, B complex, C, and E and essential fatty acids.

Phrynoderma are keratotic follicular papules commonly present over the elbows and knees. They can also extend to the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. It is also known as toad skin. 

When it occurs due to vitamin A deficiency, it is associated with ophthalmic symptoms like xerophthalmia, night blindness, and Bitot's spots and cutaneous symptoms like xerosis, scaling, and acne.

Management includes nutritional improvement through diet, multivitamin supplementation, and treatment of the underlying cause.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis?
  1. Insulin and thyroxine decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  2. Cortisol and glucagon decrease HMG CoA reductase activity.
  3. Statins inhibit HMG CoA reductase.
  4. Cholesterol increases HMG CoA reductase activity.
  5. Cholesterol represses transcription of HMG CoA reductase mRNA.
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true regarding the regulation of cholesterol synthesis.

HMG CoA reductase is the principal enzyme involved in the regulation of cholesterol synthesis. Cholesterol is synthesized from acetyl-CoA mainly in the liver and intestine. This process occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytosol.

HMG-CoA reductase reduces HMG-CoA to mevalonate by NADPH in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. This principal regulatory step is targeted by statins, which are drugs that efficiently lower cholesterol by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase.

Activity of HMG-CoA reductase is influenced by the following factors:

  • By-products of the cholesterol synthesis pathway: Mevalonate, the immediate product of the reaction, and cholesterol, the main product of the pathway, inhibit enzyme activity. These metabolites also repress transcription of HMG-CoA reductase mRNA by inhibiting sterol regulatory element-binding protein (SREBP) transcription factor.
  • Hormones: Insulin and thyroid hormones increase enzyme activity, whereas glucagon or glucocorticoids decrease it.
  • Posttranslational modifications: Phosphorylation–dephosphorylation reactions affect enzyme activity. AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylates and inactivates the enzyme.
  • Diurnal variation

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids is found only in the mitochondria and helps in the mitochondrial function?
questions.solution:
Cardiolipin is the phospholipid found only in the mitochondria. 

Cardiolipin is an important component of the inner mitochondrial membrane. It is essential for the optimal function of numerous mitochondrial enzymes involved in mitochondrial energy metabolism and for the maintenance of the mitochondrial membrane structure. 

Decreased cardiolipin or alteration in its metabolism results in mitochondrial dysfunction. This is seen in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy) which is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to small numbers of white blood cells (neutropenia), and short stature.

questions.text: You are studying the visual pigment cycle in the physiology lab. Identify the substance that converts cis-retinal to trans-retinal.
questions.solution:
The substance that converts cis-retinal to trans-retinal is rhodopsin.

Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in the outer segment of rods responsible for scotopic vision (night/ dark vision). It is a light-sensitive pigment and consists of opsin and 11-cis retinal.

When light is absorbed by rhodopsin, it decomposes very quickly. This leads to an instantaneous change of the cis form of retinal into an all-trans form. This all-trans-retinal separates from scotopsin to produce bathorhodopsin. Bathorhodopsin is very unstable and decays to form lumirhodopsin, which then decays and forms metarhodopsin I, metarhodopsin II, and finally, into the completely split products scotopsin and all-trans-retinal. 

Metarhodopsin II is also called activated rhodopsin, and it produces excitatory changes in the rods, which transmits optic nerve action potentials. to the central nervous system.

Re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal back into 11-cis retinal. This requires metabolic energy and is catalyzed by retinal isomerase. 11-cis retinal then recombines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin. Rhodopsin now remains stable until it is triggered by light energy to start decomposing again.

Role of vitamin A: The second route of re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal into all-trans-retinol, which is a form of vitamin A. All-trans-retinol is converted into 11- cis retinol by isomerase. 11-cis retinol is then converted into 11-cis retinal, combines with scotopsin, and forms new rhodopsin.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed newborn was brought with vomiting and diarrhea that developed since birth. On examination, the baby is jaundiced and has hepatomegaly. Blood glucose level was low and erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level was elevated. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an exclusively breastfed infant with vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly with elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level is suggestive of classical galactosemia.

Classical galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. The enzyme deficient here is galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features include vomiting, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, jaundice, congenital cataracts, aminoaciduria, and failure to thrive. There is an increased incidence of Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis. Long-term complications include speech delays, learning impairment, motor dysfunction, and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (in females).

The presence of galactose in urine (positive Benedict's test), elevated blood galactose level, and elevated erythrocyte galactose-1-phosphate level help in confirming the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet. Supportive therapy and the prevention of complications are important.

Other options:

Option A: Fructosuria is due to the deficiency of fructokinase. There are no symptoms except for the benign excretion of fructose in urine.

Option B: von Gierke's disease is due to glucose-6-phosphatase or translocase deficiency. It is a glycogen storage disorder (Type I).  They may develop hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis in the neonatal period, but hepatomegaly usually develops at 3–4 months. They may have doll-like facies, short stature, and a protuberant abdomen. Hyperuricemia, the elevation of triglycerides, low-density lipoproteins, and phospholipids are seen.

Option D: Hereditary fructose intolerance is due to a deficiency of fructose 1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (aldolase B). Patients are healthy and symptom-free until fructose or sucrose is ingested. Clinical manifestations may include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. It will not be seen in newborns who are exclusively on breast milk.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with sudden onset of severe breathlessness with wheezing. Her peak expiratory flow rate is reduced significantly. Which of the following enzymes is important for the pathogenesis of the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset of severe breathlessness and wheezing with a reduced peak expiratory flow rate is suggestive of acute exacerbation of asthma. 5-lipoxygenase enzyme is important for the pathogenesis of this condition. 

Acute exacerbation of asthma is characterized by bronchoconstriction due to chemicals mediators like leukotrienes (LTB4, LTC4, LTD4 etc.). Leukotrienes are produced from the breakdown of arachidonic acid by 5-lipoxygenase via the lipoxygenase pathway. 

Leukotrienes are eicosanoic acid derivatives formed in leukocytes, mast cells, platelets, and macrophages. They are potent constrictors of the bronchial airway. Leukotrienes also cause increased vascular permeability and activation and attraction of leukocytes. Thus, they are involved in many inflammatory or immediate hypersensitivity reactions, such as asthma.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented to the casualty in an unconscious state. His blood sugars were high, the ABG(Arterial blood gas) analysis showed metabolic acidosis, and urine tests were positive for ketone bodies. The ketone bodies were not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme:
questions.solution:
Ketone bodies are not utilized in the liver because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

The above clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis characterized by excess production of ketone bodies. The liver cannot utilize the ketone bodies (acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase (also called succinyl CoA acetoacetyl CoA transferase).

Ketone bodies are synthesized in the liver mitochondria (by ketogenesis) and transported in the blood to the peripheral tissues. Here they are utilized by the following steps:

  1. β-hydroxybutyrate (the most predominant ketone body) is oxidized to acetoacetate by β-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase producing NADH.
  2. Acetoacetate is then activated to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA by succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).
  3. Acetoacetyl CoA is cleaved into two acetyl CoA molecules by thiolase and oxidized into CO2 by the TCA cycle.

When higher than normal ketone bodies are present in the blood or urine, it is called ketonemia or ketonuria, respectively. The overall condition is called ketosis. The metabolism of free fatty acids to produce ketone bodies is exaggerated in pathologic states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, thus causing ketosis. The continued buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the alkali reserve, causing ketoacidosis.

questions.text: A young man with a family history of coronary heart disease asks you for advice on prevention and you prescribe omega 3 capsules. To which of the following fatty acid groups does it belong?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, omega-3 fatty acids are useful in those with a higher preponderance of cardiovascular diseases and they come under the category of polyunsaturated fatty acids. 

They have been found to have anti-inflammatory effects and facilitate the production of less inflammatory prostaglandins and leukotrienes as compared to omega-6 fatty acids. 

Dietary omega-3 PUFA can also:

  • Suppress cardiac arrhythmias
  • Reduce blood TAG
  • Decrease tendency for thrombosis

Option A: Monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) contain a single double bond, Ex: palmitoleic acid (ω7), oleic acid (ω9), and elaidic acid (ω9). They are present in most plant-based oils. When saturated fats are replaced with MUFA, they lower the total plasma cholesterol and LDL. However, they have no anti-inflammatory properties.

Option B: Saturated fatty acid has hydrocarbon chains that do not contain any double bonds. Consumption of saturated fats is associated with high levels of total plasma cholesterol and LDL-C and an increased risk of CHD. The main sources of saturated fatty acids are dairy and meat products and some vegetable oils (coconut, palm oils).

Option C: Trans fatty acids are chemically classified as unsaturated fatty acids but behave more like saturated fatty acids in the body as they elevate LDL-C and lower HDL-C, thereby increasing the risk of CHD. They are a by-product of the hydrogenation of vegetable oils.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found to have right-sided colon cancer. His father had similar colon cancer and died at the age of 40. His paternal aunt suffers from endometrial cancer and his paternal uncle also suffers from urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lynch syndrome or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and mismatch repair is the defective DNA repair mechanism here. 

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc. It is the most common cause of the syndromic form of colon cancer. Colon cancers are seen at younger ages and usually on the right side.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

Other options:

Option A: Defects in the nucleotide excision repair pathway are seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option B: Defects in non-homologous end-joining are seen in patients with subacute combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Defects in DNA base excision repair are seen in patients with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP) syndromes. 

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history are suggestive of xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER). The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also, numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis are seen on the entire front of the face.

 Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

Skin changes begin in infancy or early childhood, mainly in sun-exposed areas. The skin lesions include erythema, scaling, bullae, freckles, telangiectasia, keratoses, basal and squamous cell carcinomas, and malignant melanomas. Eye manifestations include photophobia, blepharitis, keratitis, corneal opacities, eyelid tumors, and possible blindness. Neurologic abnormalities occur rarely in the form of cognitive deterioration and sensorineural deafness.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP, there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure, and hence the accumulation of mutations that cause cancers.

questions.text: A 20-year-old bodybuilder presented with fatigue on moderate exercise. He had recently started eating raw eggs for protein. Which of the following enzymes is likely deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The patient developed pyruvate carboxylase enzyme deficiency.

Individuals who eat an excess of uncooked egg-white develop biotin deficiency and as a result carboxylase enzyme deficiency. This is because a protein called avidin present in the egg-white binds to biotin in the diet and makes biotin unavailable for intestinal absorption. Biotin deficiency can cause dermatitis, mental status changes (depression, hallucinations), paraesthesia and alopecia.

Biotin serves as a co-enzyme for the synthesis of several carboxylase enzymes such as acetyl-CoA carboxylase, pyruvate carboxylase, propionyl CoA carboxylase and methylcrotonyl-CoA carboxylase. Thus these enzymes are deficient in biotin deficiency.

questions.text: A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli. in a glucose deficient and lactose present medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps lactose gain access into the cells?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 3 is the lac Y gene which helps lactose gain access into the cells. It does so by encoding for the enzyme, lactose permease.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium E. coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. The genetic arrangement of the lac operon helps coordinate the expression of the three main enzymes (5, 6, 7 below) involved in lactose metabolism. The genes include:

  1. lac I- it codes for the repressor protein that prevents transcription of the distal structural genes, lac Z, lac Y, and lac A by interfering with the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter.
  2. CRE (cAMP response element)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.
  3. Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 
  4. Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.
  5. lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 
  6. lac Y- encodes for lactose permease which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells
  7. lac A- encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought with complaints of a fishy smell in his hands, feet, saliva, and urine. A urinalysis revealed the substance responsible for the odor, and a diagnosis of Fish odor syndrome was made. Which is the substance responsible for this characteristic body odor?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of fish odor syndrome, the characteristic odor is due to trimethylamine (TMA), which is released in sweat, urine, and breath.

Fish odor syndrome (trimethylaminuria) is an autosomal recessive disease. It is due to a deficiency of flavin-containing monooxygenase 3 (FMO3) which converts the amino acid, TMA (trimethylamine) to TMA-N-oxide (which is non-odorous) in the liver. TMA thus builds up in the body and is released in sweat, urine, and breath, giving off a strong odor of rotting fish from the body.

Patients present in childhood or early adulthood with halitosis or body odor (distinctive fishy odor). Patients suffer from psychosocial problems such as shame, anxiety, depression, etc. Diagnosis is based on high levels of excreted trimethylamine (TMA) in the patient's urine. 

Treatment involves avoiding foods containing choline such as egg, liver, peas, and soy products. A short course of antibiotics such as neomycin and metronidazole can be given which reduce the production of trimethylamine by the gut bacteria.

questions.text:
An infant presents with poor feeding. He has tachycardia and tachypnoea along with enlarged tongue, hypotonia, skeletal muscle weakness, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH, and urine glucose tetrasaccharide. Chest X-ray is done later as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

CK-creatine kinase ; AST-aspartate aminotransferase ; ALT-alanine aminotransferase ; LDH-lactate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
From the above-given clinical scenario and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly (tachycardia and tachypnoea), Pompe's disease is the most likely diagnosis. The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and macroglossia. 

Pompe's disease (Type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiencyleading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. It can appear within weeks or months after birth (infantile Pompe disease) or may appear late in juvenile, childhood, or adulthood disease (late-onset Pompe disease).

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Urine glucose tetrasaccharide, a glycogen breakdown metabolite, is a reliable biomarker for disease severity and treatment response.

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen. It is diagnosed by detecting the decreased activity of the enzyme, α-1,4-glucosidase in the dried blood spots, leukocytes, blood mononuclear cells, muscle, or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Other options

Option A- Von Gierke disease occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Patients present commonly in 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C- McArdle disease occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D- Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice (serum bilirubin levels over 20 mg/dL) and accompanying brain damage.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: A hormone, with the structure as shown below, is being administered to a patient. It is known that it is released during the well-fed state and that it induces the rate-limiting enzyme of a reaction. Choose the correct pair of the rate-limiting enzyme induced and the reaction it is involved in.
questions.solution:
The hormone whose structure is shown in the image is insulin which is released in the well-fed state. Insulin induces the enzyme phosphofructokinase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme in glycolysis.

Glycolysis is a pathway in which glucose is converted to pyruvate in aerobic conditions or lactate in anaerobic conditions, along with the production of a small amount of energy. The rate-limiting reaction in glycolysis is the phosphorylation of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose 1,6-bisphosphate. This is catalyzed by the enzyme phosphofructokinase.

There are two phosphofructokinases, PFK-1 and PFK-2 which participate in this reaction. PFK-1 plays a key role in regulating glycolysis and is subject to feedback control. It converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bis-phosphate.

Inhibitors of PFK-1:

  • ATP
  • Citrate

Allosteric activators of PFK-1:

  • AMP
  • Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (most potent activator)

Hormonal regulation:

  • Inducer—Insulin
  • Repressor—Glucagon

Due to the inhibition of phosphofructokinase-1 by ATP, there is an accumulation of glucose-6-phosphate, which in turn inhibits the uptake of glucose in extrahepatic tissues.

PFK-2 phosphorylates fructose-6-phosphate to form fructose-2-6-bis-phosphate in the fed state. PFK-2 also acts as fructose bisphosphatase-2 (FBPase-2) and breaks down fructose 2,6-bisphosphate to fructose-6-phosphate in the fasting state. Hence, PFK-2 is a bifunctional enzyme whose function is reversed by the presence of insulin or glucagon in the fed and fasting states respectively. 

The primary structure of insulin consists of 2 polypeptide chains: A-chain (21 amino acids) and B-chain (30 amino acids).
 
It has two interchain disulfide bonds, 
  • Between the 7th amino acid of the A chain and the 7th amino acid of the B chain 
  • Between the 20th amino acid of the A chain and the 19th amino acid of the B chain

One intrachain disulfide bond is present between the 6th amino acid of the A-chain and the 11th amino acid in the A-chain.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient comes with a history of chronic weight loss, loss of appetite, and diarrhea along with pale bulky stools and is diagnosed with malabsorption syndrome. Steatorrhea is defined in this patient by stool fat exceeding:
questions.solution:
Steatorrhea is a symptom defined by stool fat exceeding 7 g per day.

Steatorrhea is the passage of greasy, foul-smelling, difficult-to-flush stools. It is often associated with weight loss & nutritional deficiencies due to concomitant malabsorption of amino acids & fat-soluble vitamins. It is one of the clinical features of fat malabsorption and is noted in many conditions causing intraluminal maldigestion, mucosal malabsorption, or lymphatic obstruction.

Causes of steatorrhea:

  • Exocrine pancreatic insufficiency: Chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis (CF), pancreatic tumors
  • Bile acid deficiency: Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC), primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC), ileal resection, Crohn disease, small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO)
  • Enteropathy or Malabsorption syndrome: Celiac disease (most common), tropical sprue, giardiasis, Whipple disease, amyloidosis, SIBO, abetalipoproteinemia

Screening of steatorrhea is by the detection of fat by Sudan III staining. Stool fat can be quantified by calculating the coefficient of fat absorption (CFA), which is an essential step in the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. 

Refsum's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood. 

In this condition, the enzyme phytanoyl CoA hydroxylase is defective and causes the accumulation of phytanic acid. Clinically, patients present with dysmorphic facies and severe neurological symptoms such as polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, ichthyosis, and cerebellar ataxia. Regression of symptoms is observed with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Therefore, management includes avoiding sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, nuts, and green leafy vegetables.

Note: The Zellweger spectrum is a continuum of diseases of persoxisome defects with Zellweger syndrome (most severe) at one end, neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy in the middle (intermediate severity) and infantile Refsum's disease (least severe) at the other end.

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX/Peroxin family of genes involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes. There is severe neurologic symptoms and patients usually die in the 1st year of life.

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is a disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes.

questions.text: An undernourished child is brought for consultation. You prescribe a mineral supplement that is absorbed by the mechanism shown in the image below. Identify the supplement.
questions.solution:
The given image shows iron absorption and transport from a duodenal enterocyte into the blood, hence the mineral supplement prescribed can be identified as an iron supplement.

The following image shows in detail, the absorption of iron from a duodenal enterocyte.

Dietary iron is available in two forms - heme and non-heme iron. Initially, the ferric non-heme iron is reduced to ferrous iron by duodenal cytochrome B (ferric reductase) or by vitamin C. The reduced ferrous iron is then transferred into the enterocyte by DMT 1 (divalent metal transporter). 

Heme iron moves into the cytoplasm with the help of transporters. Here, it is metabolized to release ferrous iron, which then follows the same pathway as non-heme iron.

Once inside the enterocyte, it can either get stored as ferritin or transferred across the basolateral membrane by ferroportin. In the plasma, iron is transported in the Fe3+ form bound to transferrin, which is a transport protein. Hephaestin is a ferroxidase that oxidizes Fe2+ to Fe3+ before it is transported.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby iron absorption too. Thus, iron is trapped in the intestinal cells which is eventually sloughed off. Hepcidin also inhibits the release of iron from macrophages by binding to ferroportin. High hepcidin levels are seen in systemic inflammation and low hepcidin levels are seen in hemochromatosis.

Iron is an important component of

  • Hemoglobin
  • Myoglobin
  • Cytochrome P450 groups of enzymes
  • Components of the electron transport chain
  • Ribonucleotide reductase

questions.text: Which among the following enzymes does not contribute in the reversible phase of the pentose phosphate pathway?
questions.solution:
6-phosphogluconate dehydrogenase is involved in the irreversible oxidative phase of the pentose phosphate pathway. Transketolase, keto-isomerase, and phosphohexose isomerase are involved in the reversible non-oxidative phase.

The pentose phosphate pathway, also known as the HMP shunt pathway, is an alternative route for the metabolism of glucose. It contributes by two major ways:

  • Formation of NADPH for the synthesis of fatty acids and steroids and maintenance of reduced glutathione for antioxidant activity
  • Formation of ribose for the synthesis of nucleic acid and nucleotides

The enzymes for this pathway are found in the cytosol. There are two phases:

  1. Irreversible oxidative phase: Glucose-6-phosphate is dehydrogenated and decarboxylated to form ribulose-5- phosphate.
  2. Reversible nonoxidative phase: Ribulose-5-phosphate is converted back to glucose-6-phosphate.

Clinical significance:

  • Protection against hemolysis: NADPH is utilized for the reduction of oxidized glutathione. Reduced glutathione removes H2O2, thereby preventing oxidative damage to RBCs and hemolysis. Thus, deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase results in hemolytic anemia.
  • Formation of glucoronate: Glucose-6-phosphate gives rise to glucoronate via the uronic acid pathway. Glucoronate is important as a precursor for proteoglycans and as a conjugate for substances like steroid hormones and drugs for their excretion in bile or urine. A deficiency in the uronic acid pathway results in essential pentosuria.
  • Fructose and galactose metabolism: Fructose bypasses the regulatory step in the HMP pathway and undergoes rapid glycolysis in the liver. This results in increased fatty acid synthesis and VLDL secretion. Galactose formed from glucose is an essential constituent of lactose, glycolipids, proteoglycans, and glycoproteins. Deficiencies of enzymes in these reactions lead to metabolic diseases like essential fructosuria, hereditary fructose intolerance, and galactosemia.
  • Formation of amino sugars: Amino sugars are formed from glucose and are important components of glycoproteins, glycosphingolipids, and glycosaminoglycans.

questions.text: While conducting a health camp, you host an awareness campaign on healthy dietary practices. Which of the following substances would you say has the highest respiratory quotient immediately after consumption?
questions.solution:
The food item with the highest respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after consumption is a mixed diet. 

This is because, immediately after a mixed meal (containing carbohydrates, protein, and fat), carbohydrates is the most commonly metabolized component, so the RQ reaches 1. But, a few hours after, the body would have used up the readily available carbohydrates, and the RQ reaches 0.70, due to fat metabolism.

The respiratory quotient is the ratio of carbon dioxide produced/oxygen consumed. The respiratory quotient for various substances:

Substance RQ
Carbohydrate 1.00 
Protein (option D) 0.81 
Fat (option B) 0.71  
Alcohol (option C) 0.66 

In diabetes, the rate of utilization of carbohydrates reduces in relation to fats, hence RQ falls (approximately 0.7). The RQ is lowest when ketosis is very active.

Note: For all metabolic fuels, the energy produced is the same (20 kJ/L of oxygen).

questions.text: A young man with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. During treatment, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. His blood picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. questions.text: Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) is used in order to identify the five different species of staphylococci in a surgical ICU. Which of the following site does the restriction enzyme act on?
questions.solution:
The restriction enzyme is likely to act on 5'-GATATC-3' (Option B).

Restriction endonuclease(RE) enzymes usually act at specific palindromic sequences which create DNA fragments of different lengths. A palindromic sequence is one that reads the same in opposite directions. By analyzing the fragments produced after cutting the DNA by RE, specific species of bacteria can be identified. Option B, when expanded after writing the complementary sequence, appears the same while reading both DNA strands in the 5' to 3' direction and is hence a palindrome.

5' --GATATC-- 3'
3' --CTATAG-- 5' 

Restriction endonucleases are enzymes that recognize and cleave a specific double-stranded DNA sequence. These DNA cuts result in sticky ends or blunt ends. Sticky ends are then used to build hybrid DNA. 

A Restriction fragment length poly­morphism (RFLP) is a genetic variant that can be studied by cleaving the DNA into fragments known as restriction fragments. This is done using a restriction enzyme. The length of the restriction fragments changes if the genetic variant alters the DNA and creates or abolishes the site of restriction endonuclease cleavage. RFLPs can thus be used to find the variation in different staphylococci species.

The sequences given in Options A, C and D are not palindromes, as they do not read the same forwards and backwards after expanding. So they cannot be recognized by Restriction endonuclease enzymes.

questions.text: A man presented with slurred speech and festinating shuffling gait. He tells that a course of levodopa was advised by his previous doctor but didn't show any effect. Which of the following mineral toxicity/ deficiency causes such features?
questions.solution:
Manganese toxicity can cause secondary parkinsonism with features similar to atypical parkinsonism.

Secondary parkinsonism is characterized by Parkinson-like disease caused by agents/factors that cause basal ganglia dysfunction. These factors include drugs (tetrabenazine, metoclopramide, neuroleptics, flunarizine), stroke, tumor, infection, or toxins. Clinical features will be based on the region of the basal ganglia that has been damaged.

Toxins such as carbon monoxide or manganese produce damage to the globus pallidus, and hence present with features resembling atypical parkinsonism such as:

  • Early speech and gait impairment
  • Repeated early falls
  • Absence of rest tremor
  • No motor asymmetry
  • Poor or no response to levodopa
  • Aggressive clinical course
  • Symptoms of severe early autonomic involvement

Manganese deficiency on the other hand can result in poor growth, bone demineralization, ataxia, convulsions, and abnormalities in carbohydrate and lipid metabolism.

Other options

Option A: Selenium deficiency causes Keshan disease (cardiomyopathy in endemic regions of China); Excess selenium intake leads to selenosis (with hair loss, brittle nails, garlic breath odor, myopathy, and neurologic symptoms).

Option B: Zinc toxicity leads to nausea, vomiting, headache, fever, and hypersalivation. Zinc deficiency causes dwarfism, hypogonadism, hypopigmented hair, hypogeusia, and impaired immunity.

Option D: Hypomagnesemia is characterized by neurologic symptoms like tremors, muscle weakness, ataxia, delirium, and psychosis. Hypermagnesemia causes lethargy, weakness, hypotonia, weak tendon reflexes, and coma.

questions.text: A middle-aged man with a history of chronic alcohol comsuption presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia and diplopia. What is the protocol to treat this patient?

choices.text: Thiamine injection followed by glucose infusion

Diplopia, ataxia and confusion in a patient with chronic alcohol consumption  is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy. The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

  1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by global confusion, truncal ataxia, ophthalmoplegia and horizontal nystagmus.
  2. Korsakoff psychosis: Symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include memory loss and confabulation
  3. Beriberi: It can be either -

    • Wet beriberi: Tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room in a state of altered sensorium, irritability, and aggression. His relatives give a history of a headache earlier that day, for which the patient had taken a paracetamol tablet. On further investigation, he was found to have a deficiency of citrin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is type II citrullinemia.

Type II citrullinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the deficiency of citrin due to mutations in the SLC25A13 gene. Citrin is a membrane transport protein in the urea cycle that facilitates the transfer of aspartate from mitochondria to the cytoplasm.

Patients usually present between 20 and 50 years of age, with neuropsychiatric symptoms like altered mental status, confusion, seizures, flapping tremors, irritability, or even a coma-like state resulting from hepatic encephalopathy. There are recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia which are usually precipitated by triggers like surgery, drugs (like acetaminophen), alcohol consumption, and high sugar intake. The patient will also have a history of aversion to carbohydrate-rich foods like rice, bread, and potato.

During an acute attack, elevated levels of ammonia, citrulline, and arginine are observed with low or normal levels of glutamine. Levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the RBCs are also increased. Demonstration of the gene mutation is useful for confirmation of the diagnosis.

It is managed with a diet that is rich in fats and proteins and low in carbohydrates with supplements of medium-chain triglycerides, arginine, and pyruvate. Liver transplantation helps to prevent the progression of symptoms.

Note: Deficiency of any of the urea cycle enzymes would result in hyperammonemia

Other options:

Option A: Type I citrullinemia is a urea cycle disorder caused by a deficiency of argininosuccinate synthase, which catalyzes the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate; Patients have a history of protein aversion, lethargy progressing to coma, and liver failure.

Option C: Hartnup disease is caused due to a defective intestinal transport of the essential amino acids such as tryptophan and niacin. Clinical features include pellagra like rash and neurologic manifestations such as cerebellar ataxia and delirium.

Option D: Type I hyperammonemia is also a urea cycle disorder caused due to a deficiency of the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthase-I, which is essential for the condensation of CO2, ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. Clinical features include irritability, vomiting, lethargy (especially a few days after birth).

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought with a history of impaired vision and severe photophobia. On examination, he has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue eyes. A disorder due to deficiency in the enzyme tyrosinase is suspected. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosinase point to the diagnosis of albinism. 

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterised by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. The first step in melanin synthesis involves the oxidation of L-tyrosine to DOPA by the enzyme tyrosinase. Tyrosinase further acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which undergoes a series of reactions to form melanin. 

Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. 

Other options-

Option B- Tyrosinemia type 1 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical findings include cirrhosis, liver failure, rickets, failure to thrive, peripheral neuropathy, and boiled cabbage odour. 

Option C- Tyrosinemia type 2 is caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme tyrosine transaminase. Clinical findings include palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions with photophobia, and learning disability. 

Option D- Homocystinuria is caused due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. Clinical findings include lens dislocation, thrombotic vascular disease, intellectual disability, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: You are evaluating the metabolic changes in patients with various conditions. Increased basal metabolic rate will be seen in patients with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in patients with acromegaly.

High energy-requiring states such as fever, pregnancy, pheochromocytoma, adrenergic agonist drugs, cancer, congestive heart failure, acromegaly, polycythemia, and Paget’s disease of the bone are associated with high BMR. Obesity, starvation or anorexia, hypogonadism, Addison's syndrome, and immobilization are associated with low BMR.

BMR is the energy required by an awake individual during rest. It is the minimum energy required to carry out vital functions of the body such as respiration, circulation, etc. 

It is calculated using oxygen consumption, calorific value (energy produced by 1 liter of oxygen), and surface area.

BMR is dependent on various factors:

  • Men have more BMR than women of the same body weight and age because women’s bodies contain proportionally more adipose tissue and fewer muscles. 
  • Elderly people have less BMR as the muscle tissue gets infiltrated with fat as age advances.
  • Low environmental temperature is associated with high BMI.
  • Exercise increases BMR.
  • The thyroid hormone has a direct role in increasing BMR.

A 45-year-old male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin as shown below. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin. Identify the false statement regarding the patient's illness.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda. The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. The hepatic iron stores will be increased in this condition.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common type of porphyria and presents with cutaneous and hepatic features. It is caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene are present in the familial type PCT.

The accumulated porphyrins are transported to the skin and act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin friability, milia, and bullae on the sun-exposed skin of the dorsal aspect of the hands, forearms, face, legs, and feet. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

The porphyrins accumulate in the liver and are excreted in urine and bile. Hepatic iron stores are increased as PCT is an iron-related disorder. Liver dysfunction is common in these patients and the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma is increased. 

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

Management includes:

  • Repeated phlebotomies to deplete hepatic iron stores. Iron administration can lead to a recurrence of the disease.
  • Low dose hydroxychloroquine which forms complexes and removes the excess porphyrins from the liver.

questions.text: A 15-month-old child is brought because of developmental delay and clouded appearance of the cornea in both eyes. The other examination findings of the child are shown in the image below. The elder sibling of the child also has similar findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The given image shows coarse facial features, umbilical hernia, claw hand, and thoracolumbar gibbus. These features along with corneal opacity and developmental delay are highly suggestive of mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS).

The features mentioned in the above question are suggestive of MPS type 1. It is caused by the deficiency of α-l-iduronidase, leading to the storage of dermatan and heparan sulfate. The classical form of MPS 1 is known as Hurler syndrome, the intermediate form as Hurler–Scheie, and the most attenuated form is known as Scheie syndrome.

Mucopolysaccharidoses (MPS) are a group of genetic disorders (inborn errors of metabolism) affecting glycosaminoglycans (GAGs). They are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and involve mutations of genes encoding lysosomal hydroxylases. Diagnosis is by demonstration of GAGs in urine or tissue biopsy samples, assays of suspected defective enzymes in white blood cells, fibroblasts, or serum, and testing for specific genes.

Option D: Refsum disease - It is a disorder of fatty acid metabolism. It occurs due to deficiency of alpha-hydroxylase causing phytanic acid accumulation in the tissues. It presents with neurological symptoms, cerebellar ataxia, retinitis pigmentosa, and polyneuropathy.

questions.text: You are a researcher studying the mechanism of action of statins which inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase by acting as a structural analog to its natural substrate. The Lineweaver Burk Plot for the interaction is given below. Which of the following is true about this type of inhibition?
questions.solution:
The given example of statin inhibiting cholesterol synthesis by acting on HMG-CoA reductase and the graph is a type of competitive inhibition. True about competitive inhibition is that the Km of the reaction increases.

Important parameters in a reaction include:

  • The affinity of the enzyme for its substrate is given by the Michaelis constant or Km. A low Km reflects a high affinity of the enzyme for substrate and vice versa. The value of Km is given by the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is equal to one-half Vmax. It does not change with changes in enzyme concentration. 
  • The rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the enzyme concentration.

Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds reversibly to the substrate-binding site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme binding site.

This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Noncompetitive inhibition is by binding of inhibitors to enzymes in locations remote from the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition. Thus, noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented with chronic pain in the lower back and knees. On physical examination, there were black pigmentary deposits on the sclera of both eyes and on the fingers and nailbeds. The urine turned black on exposure to Benedict's reagent and showed large amounts of a particular metabolite which is responsible. Identify the metabolite from the image below
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of alkaptonuria, which is characterised by excretion of the metabolite homogentisate (marked as 2 in the flowchart) in urine.

Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of tyrosine metabolism. It occurs due to a defect in homogentisate oxidase (which oxidizes homogentisate to maleylacetoacetate) leading to the accumulation of homogentisate. The excreted homogentisate in urine makes it appear black when it gets oxidized on exposure to air or an oxidizing agent.

Accumulation of oxidized homogentisic acid pigment (benzoquinone acetate) in joints and connective tissues leads to arthritis and connective tissue pigmentation respectively. This is known as ochronosis. Pigmentation of heart valves, larynx, tympanic membranes, and skin, with occasional renal pigment calculi, can also be seen.

Most patients are diagnosed early based on the darkening of urine with standing or the addition of alkali. Around the age of 30 years, gray-brown pigmentation of sclera and generalized darkening of the concha, anthelix and helix of the ear is seen.Some patients present in middle age with a degenerative joint disease (ochronotic arthritis) with pain, stiffness, and limitation of motion of the lower back, hips, knees, and shoulders. Small joints are usually spared.

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic treatment with pain medications, spinal surgery, and arthroplasty 
  • Ascorbic acid and protein restriction 
  • Nitisinone - reduces urinary excretion of homogentisic acid and delays progression of the disease.

questions.text: A young boy with a metabolic disorder has long slender fingers, tall stature, and a high arched palate. He is fair-skinned, with blue eyes and a malar flush. On ophthalmological examination, there is a bilateral inferonasal subluxation of the lens. This disorder is due to abnormal metabolism of:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with tall stature, long limbs, inferonasal subluxation of the lens, with blue eyes, fair skin, and a malar flush is suggestive of homocystinuria, which is due to the abnormal metabolism of methionine.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive disorder of methionine metabolism. It is due to a defect in the enzyme cystathionine β-synthase whose function is to convert homocysteine to cystathionine. This leads to an abnormal accumulation of homocysteine and its metabolites (homocysteine, homocysteine-cysteine complex, and others) in blood and urine, along with low levels of cysteine in plasma. 

Clinical features:

  • Affected infants appear normal at birth. 
  • Ectopia lentis (inferonasal subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age. There may be severe myopia and iridodonesis (quivering iris).
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes especially in the large and small vessels of the brain.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers). There may be scoliosis, a high arched palate, and crowding of teeth.
  • Fair skin, blue eyes, and a malar flush

Diagnosis is by elevated levels of methionine and homocysteine in body fluids. Additional tests include molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) and enzyme assay in cultured fibroblasts, lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens.

Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, and folate.

questions.text: An eight-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body along with a history of wide-based, unsteady gait. On examination, serum electrolytes are normal and urine is positive for neutral amino acids. The pattern of inheritance of the disease is given in the image below.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra-like symptoms with autosomal recessive inheritance as shown in the image is suggestive of Hartnup disease. It is due to a tryptophan transport defect.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to a mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on Chromosome 5. This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia(wide-based unsteady gait), tremors, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, distinguishing it from pellagra. Indican can also be present in the urine, produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Treatment involves supplementation with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.  

Other options :

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase defect is seen in acute intermittent porphyria, which is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It presents with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. There will be elevated aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Option C: Methylcobalamin formation defect results in methylmalonic acidemia, which follows autosomal recessive inheritance. The clinical manifestations would include vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures. 

Option D: Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency results in tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Patients present with corneal inflammation, painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and mental retardation.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct with respect to the histones in state A (methylation) and state B (acetylation) in the given image?
  1. A results in the expression of genes. 
  2. B is associated with chromosomal assembly during DNA replication.
  3. Both A and B are epigenetic changes,
  4. Both A and B are types of post-translational modifications (PTMs).
  5. Both A and B are reversible.
questions.solution:
The given image shows histone modification by methylation (state A) and acetylation (state B). 2, 3, 4, and 5 are the correct statements regarding the two images.

In state A, methylation of DNA and Histones causes nucleosomes to be tightly packed together. Transcription factors cannot bind to the DNA, therefore the genes will not be expressed (statement 1 is false). In state B, histone acetylation results in loose packing of the nucleosomes. The target gene is accessible and transcription factors can bind to the DNA and genes are expressed. 

Acetylation and methylation are epigenetic changes, i.e, additional DNA changes that alter gene expression without altering the structure of the inherited base sequence of DNA. (Statement 3).

The organizational unit of the soluble chromatin is the nucleosome. Chromatin contain DNA and histones (small basic proteins), non-histone proteins and RNA (in smaller quantities).

Four major types of histones: H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 are tightly bound, have a fixed sequence and form the nucleosome, hence called the core histones. H1 histones are least tightly bound to chromatin.

These four core histones undergo covalent modification or posttranslational modifications (PTMs) (Statement 4). These histone modifications play important roles in chromatin structure and function and can be of 6 types:

  • Acetylation
  • Methylation
  • Phosphorylation
  • ADP-ribosylation
  • Monoubiquitylation
  • Sumoylation. 

Roles of modified histones:

  • Acetylation of all core histones helps in chromosomal assembly during DNA replication (statement 2).
  • Methylation of histones is correlated with repression of gene transcription.
  • Acetylation of H3 and H4 causes activation or inactivation of gene transcription.
  • ADP-ribosylation of histones is for DNA repair.
  • Phosphorylation of histone H1 causes condensation of chromosomes during the replication cycle.
  • Monoubiquitylation is associated with gene activation, repression, and heterochromatic gene silencing.

Note: All PTMs are reversible (statement 5).

questions.text: A patient with a history of using well water for cooking and consumption presents with vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain. On examination, there is jaundice, hemoglobinuria, Mees lines on the nails, and features of hypovolemic shock. A toxicology screen is done, and the 24-hour urine sample is found to contain high amounts of a toxin.  Which enzyme of Kreb's cycle will be inhibited by this toxin?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (AKG) of Kreb's cycle is inhibited by this toxin, arsenite (inorganic arsenic salt).

α-Ketoglutarate is a rate-determining intermediate in Kreb's cycle. It has a crucial role in cellular energy metabolism as it acts as a precursor of glutamate and glutamine and promotes protein synthesis.

Alpha-ketoglutarate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form succinyl-CoA and CO2 with the help of the multienzyme complex, AKG dehydrogenase. This enzyme complex requires the cofactors, thiamin diphosphate, lipoate, NAD+, flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD), and coenzyme A.

Arsenite inhibits this decarboxylation reaction and causes the substrate, α-ketoglutarate, to accumulate. 

Arsenic toxicity is either due to inhalation of toxic arsenic gas or chronic consumption of foods cooked in contaminated well water. It presents with malaise, headache, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, hemoglobinuria, and renal failure. There may be hemorrhagic gastroenteritis, hypovolemic shock, and cardiovascular manifestations such as QT prolongation, polymorphous ventricular tachycardia, and congestive cardiomyopathy. Mees lines is a common dermatologic manifestation characterized by transverse white striae on the nail.

Arsenic toxicity is detected by measuring the 24-hour urine excretion of arsenic.


Other options: 

Option A: Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase is inhibited by iodoacetate. It is not a part of Kreb's cycle.

Option C: Aconitase is inhibited by fluoroacetate.

Option D: Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by malonate.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child has a history of biting his lips and fingers. On evaluation, you notice lip lacerations, missing portions of fingers of his hands, and developmental delay. On inquiry, the parents say that two male cousins on the mother's side with similar complaints have been diagnosed with a genetic disorder. Lab reports reveal hyperuricemia. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history and hyperuricemia is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It occurs due to the complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) involved in the salvage pathway.

Purines produced in the body or introduced through diet can be converted to nucleoside triphosphates to be reused by the body. This pathway is called the salvage pathway for purines and is shown below

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). There is increased de novo purine synthesis which produces excessive amounts of uric acid.

The clinical features include compulsive self-mutilation, intellectual disability, delayed milestones, dystonic movements, and hyperuricemia. The excess uric acid can form kidney stones (urolithiasis) or deposit in joints as urate crystals (gouty arthritis).

The treatment of this condition includes:

  • Allopurinol or febuxostat for hyperuricemia
  • Behavioral management using restraints for self-mutilation
  • High fluid intake, reduced fructose and purine intake

Partial deficiency of HGPRT leads to Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Other options:

Option A:Purine nucleoside phosphorylase deficiency leads to severe T cell deficiency with normal B cell function. Patients present with autoimmune diseases and opportunistic infections.

Option C: Adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRT) is another enzyme along with HGPRT to be involved in the salvage of purine bases to nucleotides. 

Option D: Adenosine deaminase deficiency leads to sparse or defective T cells and B cells. Patients suffer from sever immunodeficiency and often succumb to fatal infections.

Adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann–Riniker syndrome.

SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections early in life and often present with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive.

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:

It is due to deficiency of the enzyme Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase(HGPRT). It is an X-linked recessive disease.

Clinical features:

  • Hyperuricemia

questions.text:
Which of the following modifications occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA?
  1. Capping
  2. Polyadenylation
  3. Phosphorylation
  4. Trimming
  5. Splicing
  6. Hydroxylation
questions.solution:
Capping, polyadenylation, and splicing are the modifications that occur posttranscriptionally to produce a mature eukaryotic mRNA. Phosphorylation, hydroxylation, and trimming are modifications that occur posttranslationally.

A mature eukaryotic mRNA is formed after the pre-mRNA components of the heterogenous nuclear RNA (hnRNA) undergo the following posttranscriptional modifications in the nucleus:

  1. Addition of a 5′ cap: A 7-methylguanosine is attached to the 5′ terminal end of the mRNA via a 5′-to-5′ triphosphate linkage. This stabilizes the mRNA and allows initiation of translation.
  2. Addition of a 3′-poly-A tail: The poly-A tail is added by the nuclear enzyme, polyadenylate polymerase, after clevage of the polyadenylation signal sequence (AAUAAA) found near the 3′ end of the mRNA. This terminates eukaryotic transcription. Furthermore, it stabilizes the mRNA, allows it to exit from the nucleus, and helps in translation.
  3. Splicing: This is the process of removing introns (intervening sequences that do not code for proteins) and joining exons (the coding or expressed sequences), carried out by the spliceosome. Alternative splicing occurs in different tissues to produce varied number of proteins from a limited set of genes.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room with excruciating burning pain over the palms and soles, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and ringing sensation in the ears. On examination, he has thickening of lips, frontal bossing, corneal opacities, and skin lesions as shown in the image below. This X-linked disorder is caused due to which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Fabry's disease and it is caused due to the deficiency of α-Galactosidase. 

Fabry disease is an X-linked, multisystem, lysosomal storage disorder caused due to mutations in the gene that codes for α-Galactosidase, resulting in decreased activity of the enzyme. This leads to accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. It is seen in both men and women (less severe).

It usually manifests in childhood or adolescence, with symptoms of severe agonizing pain in the palms of hands, soles of feet, and proximal extremities called acroparesthesia, aggravated by changes in temperature, exercise, fatigue, or fever and may last anywhere from a few minutes to many days.

There is a characteristic facial appearance of frontal bossing, thickening of the lips, and prominent supraorbital ridges. Angiokeratomas, as seen in the image above are present, which are lesions that are dark-red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate, and usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the 'bathing suit area') and the trunk.

Patients also have diarrhea, abdominal distension, heat intolerance, and tinnitus. Late presentations include renal failure, and cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease, which are the leading causes of death in these patients.

Urinalysis shows proteinuria. An enzyme assay, genetic testing, or a skin or kidney biopsy showing glycolipid deposits helps establish the diagnosis.

Treatment is with enzyme replacement therapy (recombinant alpha-Gal A or migalastat).

Other options:

Option B: β-Glucosidase deficiency manifests as Gaucher disease, which gives rise to symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly, erosion of long bones and mental retardation in infants.

Option C: Sphingomyelinase deficiency manifests as Niemann-Pick disease, with patients presenting with symptoms of hepatosplenomegaly and mental retardation. It is usually fatal in early life.

Option D: Ceramidase deficiency manifests as Farber disease, characterised by dermatitis, hoarseness, skeletal deformities and mental retardation. It is fatal in early life.

A patient comes to you with vitamin D deficiency. You advise the patient to take a walk under sufficient sunlight everyday. What is the correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis?
  1. 7-dehydrocholesterol
  2. Cholecalciferol
  3. 25-hydroxycholecalciferol
  4. 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of products formed during vitamin D synthesis is 1-2-3-4.

Vitamin D is obtained by synthesis in the skin with adequate sunlight exposure or dietary supplementation. It helps in regulating calcium absorption and homeostasis. Deficiency results in rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults and is a common problem in areas with inadequate sunlight.

The sequence of vitamin D synthesis is:

  1. Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol is nonenzymatically converted to previtamin D on exposure to ultraviolet light. It is converted to cholecalciferol, which then enters the bloodstream.
  2. Liver: Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form 25-hydroxyvitamin D (calcidiol), which is bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin and released into the bloodstream. This is the main storage form of vitamin D. 
  3. Kidney: 25-hydroxyvitamin D is further hydroxylated to form 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol). This is the biologically active form of vitamin D. In some cases, it can also undergo 24-hydroxylation to form an inactive metabolite called 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D.

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician that his daughter has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode was positive for Benedict's test. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.
 
Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.
 
Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.
 
Reducing substances are seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.
 
Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
 
The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.


Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text: You are conducting a study on bactericidal activity of immune cells. You find that defects in the metabolism of a particular amino acid lead to dysfunction of nitric oxide production. Identify the involved amino acid.
questions.solution:
The involved amino acid is arginine, which is required for the production of nitric oxide (NO).

NO is an inflammatory mediator synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase.

The given image shows the process of nitric oxide synthesis.

The co-enzymes of NO synthase are :

  • FMN
  • FAD
  • Heme
  • Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Three isoenzymes of NO synthase:

  • eNOS (endothelial nitric oxide synthase): Found in the endothelium and plays a role in vasodilatation. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • nNOS (neural nitric oxide synthase): Found in the neural tissue and acts as a neurotransmitter. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.
  • iNOS (inducible nitric oxide synthase): TNF-α, IFN-γ and bacterial endotoxins induce hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils to produce this enzyme. It is inducible and calcium independent.

Functions of NO:

  • Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby produces smooth muscle relaxation.
  • Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and IFN-γ released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 
  • Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)
  • Neurotransmitter in the brain.

questions.text:
What is the correct sequence of events in Southern blotting?

1 - Transfer to a membrane
2 - Hybridization with a labeled probe sequence
3 - Separation of DNA fragments by electrophoresis
questions.solution:
In Southern blotting DNA fragments are first separated by electrophoresis.

  • The DNA in the gel is then made single-stranded by exposure to dilute alkali, and transferred by capillary action to the nylon membrane, which is laid over it. The relative positions of the different DNA fragments are thus preserved on the membrane.
  • The membrane is then soaked in buffer containing the labelled probe, which base pairs with the DNA fragment of interest.
  • The position of that fragment is then determined by autoradiographic (exposure of the membrane to X-ray film), or fluorescent detection of the hybridized probe.

questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate.  

The other test used for the purpose of detecting acetoacetate only is the ferric chloride test. It shows a burgundy red color that is graded from +1 to +4. False-positive results occur with drugs like salicylates and phenols. 

The image below shows the purple ring formed by a positive Rothera test.

 

Benedict's test is a test commonly used in the follow-up of diabetics for the detection of glucose in urine (glucosuria). It uses Benedict's reagent containing sodium carbonate, copper sulfate, and sodium citrate. Reducing sugars (containing a free aldehyde/ keto group) will reduce Benedict's reagent. Examples include glucose, fructose, and lactose.

The test is a semi-quantitative test. The blue color indicates no reducing sugar.

Hay's test is used for the detection of bile salts in urine. Normally, bile salts (sodium salts of taurocholic acid and glycocholic acid) are not present in urine. Thus, positive Hay's test indicates an obstructive pathology in the biliary system, leading to the backflow of bile into the circulation. This obstruction may be associated with either obstructive jaundice or hepatic jaundice.

Ehrlich's test is used to determine urinary and fecal urobilinogen. 

Porphobilinogens form a red aldehyde compound with Ehrlich reagent, which is insoluble in chloroform. A red color remaining after chloroform extraction is indicative of porphobilinogens. This test is positive in acute intermittent porphyria and hemolytic jaundice. It is negative in hepatic jaundice (later stages) and obstructive jaundice. The earliest sign of recovery in obstructive jaundice is the re-appearance of urobilinogen in urine.

questions.text: A person cycles for 4 hours on an empty stomach, causing glycogen to break down and release glucose. After reaching home, he has a full meal, leading to glucose being stored as glycogen. Which of the following enzymes is used in both these processes?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the person undergoes glycogenolysis to break down glycogen and release glucose and then undergoes glycogenesis in which glucose gets stored as glycogen. Phosphoglucomutase is involved in both glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.

The substrate for glycogenolysis is glycogen and during this process, glycogen is first converted into glucose-1-phosphate by the enzyme glycogen phosphorylase. This is a rate-limiting step in the process. Glucose-1-phosphate is then converted to glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme phosphoglucomutase and eventually, glucose is obtained from glucose-6-phosphate by the enzyme phosphatase.

During glycogenesis, glucose is phosphorylated to glucose-6-phosphate, catalyzed by hexokinase in muscle and glucokinase in the liver. Glucose-6-phosphate is isomerized to glucose-1-phosphate by phosphoglucomutase. UDP-glucose is synthesized from glucose-1-phosphate and UTP by UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase. A protein named glycogenin is the primer acting as an acceptor of glucose residues. This is glycosylated further by UDP-glucose. Glycogenin further catalyzes the transfer of seven glucose residues from UDP-Glucose, in 1 → 4 linkages, to form a glycogen primer. This in turn serves as the substrate for the enzyme, glycogen synthase, which is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycogen synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha 1,6 glucosidase is involved in glycogenolysis alone.

Option B: Glycogen Phosphorylase is involved in glycogenolysis alone.

Option D: Glycogen synthase is involved in glycogenesis alone.
